newsitem.title: UK: North sea crude weaker, Brent trades 5 cents lower.
newsitem.headline: North sea crude weaker, Brent trades 5 cents lower.

text.p: North Sea crudes weakened on Thursday as a late slump in Brent paper quotes undermined an already struggling wet market.
A Brent cargo loading Nov 8-10 traded at December Brent -40 cents, five cents down on Wednesday's deal for a 12-14 loader.
Dec paper was notionally at screen levels of $23.00/$23.05 a barrel by 1630 GMT, over 50 cents down on the day.

The rapid slide in Dec Brent from the day's high of over $23.90 a barrel put pressure on intermonth spreads with Dec/Jan talked some five cents lower at either side of +40 cents and Jan/Feb at around +50/+52 cents.
Other grades also softened with Forties shedding six cents from its last trade to change hands at a weak Dated Brent +2 cents for a cargo loading Nov 16-20.
"It's a very low number, there are just no requirements for mid-Nov," said one trader.
Another Forties cargo, loading Nov 15-20 was still to be cleared out.
Norwegian Oseberg, with the most muscle of all North Sea grades, traded at Dated Brent +30 cents, two cents down from a deal on Wednesday.
Despite weak prices in Europe, traders said that the arb to the U.S. remained closed.
"There just isn't the buying interest there, noone is working it." said one trader.
Mediterranean sour crude demand remained weak despite the closure of Novorossiisk on Thursday morning. Several Urals were still on offer, but prices stabilised after a sharp fall earlier this week.
"It's still heavy on prompt Urals, but after mid-month I think it might bounce" a trader said. Large cargoes were pegged at Dated -$1.15/$1.20 and small cargoes ten cents higher.
